urn:contentItem:5V6N-0981-JBHT-D4TM-00000-00Standing Up to Tech Giants; Fiat Chrysler Automobiles Recalls 1.6 Million Vehicles; Heavy Facebook User Danger; High-End Dog Food Delivery Boasts Food Produced to Human Standards2019-01-11T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:26:45ZLexisNexisStanding Up to Tech Giants; FiatChrysler Automobiles Recalls 1.6 Million Vehicles; Heavy Facebook User Danger; High-End Dog Food Delivery Boasts Food Produced to Human StandardsLanhamFULL TEXT

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Good morning. I'm Dagen McDowell, in for Maria Bartiromo. It's Friday, January 11th.

Your top stories at 7:00 a.m. Eastern.

The shutdown entering day 21. Tied for the longest in U.S. history. President Trump now considering declaring a national emergency and using disaster aid money to fund the border wall.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: My sacred duty, most sacred duty as president is to defend the people of our nation. That's whether it's from foreign nations or along the border. It's all defending our people. And defending them properly and strongly and really rightly, justly.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCDOWELL: Meantime futures are showing this this morning. 29 point loss, 30 point loss on the DOW futures. Investors are waiting for some headway, like some evidence that a trade deal is coming together with China, although optimistic about the progress so far.

Yesterday all three of the major market gauges gained about half of 1 percent, markets on their longest winning streak since early October.

In Europe, we have some losses to report across the board, in England, France and Germany, although slight there.

And your Asian markets -- all four major Asian markets finishing higher overnight.

Oil heading to the plus side this morning. The price of crude oil on its longest upward swing since January of 2010.

Plus, Hail Mary, details on Apple's plan for a new phone that the company hopes will pull it out of that iPhone sales slump.

And shark attack, the hit song, "Baby Shark", makes history. We will bury it in your head and you will not be able to get rid of it.

Here with me to break it all down -- CFRA investment strategist, Lindsey Bell; Forbes Media chairman and former Republican presidential candidate, Steve Forbes; and Fox News contributor, 32Advisors founder and CEO, former economic advisor to President Obama -- Robert Wolf. Welcome one and all.

ROBERT WOLF, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR: Great first hour.

MCDOWELL: You're such a flatterer.

WOLF: Great first hour.

MCDOWELL: Because you're here and you're here and you're here.

Somebody already called me a nasty name on Twitter. But I'll take that. That's fine.

STEVE FORBES, FORBES MEDIA CHAIRMAN: Just think of that shark song. It works with three-year-olds and one-year-olds.

MCDOWELL: Do you know the song -- Steve?

FORBES: I'm not going to hurt your ratings by citing it but my three-year- old can cite it.

MCDOWELL: I just love that -- deeply and profoundly. So we'll get to that later this hour.

But right now our top story -- weighing a national emergency, White House aides exploring new options to fund a southern border wall as lawmakers remain at a standstill over any deal. The White House directing the Army Corps of Engineers to divert money from other areas like disaster relief projects to secure funding if necessary.

President Trump told Sean Hannity on Fox News that a border wall is the only solution.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

TRUMP: It's common sense. It really is, when you think of it, whether you're into the world of law enforcement like these incredible folks behind us (AUDIO GAP) so easily. I mean it would make their job so much better. And they could also go to other areas because we have the wall, you don't need so many people. We would probably pay for that many times in one year.

The law is very clear. I mean we have the absolute right to declare a national emergency. And this is security stuff. This is a national emergency.

If you don't have a barrier, whether it's a steel barrier or a concrete wall, substantial and strong, you are never going to solve this problem. You're never going to solve it.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCDOWELL: Joining us now Fox News contributor, former speaker of the house and author of "Trump's America", Newt Gingrich.

Mr. Speaker -- it's always a pleasure to see you. I am dying to hear what you have to say about this. What do you say about the President potentially using emergency authority to get this wall built?

NEWT GINGRICH, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR: Well, I mean if the lawyers tell him that it will withstand a court challenge, he has every right to do it. He's commander in chief and the Congress has allocated money for the defense of the United States.

But I do think that there's a certain value to him fighting this out. Every day that goes by, it's more obvious that the Democrats don't value the safety of Americans nearly as much as they value the convenience of people trying to get here illegally.

And every day that goes by I think the fact that the Democrats won't compromise, you know, Nancy Pelosi saying if you give me everything I want, I still won't give you the wall. I think that attitude is a really bad way for them to start with a new Congress.

And so I think in many ways this is a key moment for the President in defining what's at stake for the country and in shaping the next two years.

MCDOWELL: Will the Republicans continue to stand with him? That's what -- in terms of will their knees buckle or do they have -- do they have the guts --

GINGRICH: It doesn't matter.

MCDOWELL: -- to stand with him?

GINGRICH: It doesn't matter. If he's prepared to veto a bill, he's certainly going to keep one-third plus one of the Senate and one-third plus one of the House, so he'll sustain any veto he wants. If some Republicans at the margin want to be timid, they want to be panicked, they want to run in circles, you know, the way our constitutional system works, a president who is tough and determined has enormous advantages.

And I think that he in many ways can relax and just say -- you know, first of all, Senator McConnell said he won't bring up a bill the President won't sign. So it's not going to go through the Senate.

Nancy Pelosi can -- you know, she can perform a ballet act, she can dance in circles, she can jump up and down, she would have gymnast -- it won't matter. It's not going to change anything. She can't force it through.

FORBES: Mr. Speaker, sounds like you don't think the President should declare a national emergency but simply let the thing play out. Is that what you're saying? You'd advise him not to do that? He's winning already, why mess it up?

GINGRICH: Well look, I think if you got -- I mean first of all, I think what he said all along is the right position. He is not going to sign this appropriation unless they solve --

(CROSSTALKING)

FORBES: But you don't think he should do the national emergency?

GINGRICH: -- commit themselves to solving it.

FORBES: You're saying he can't but you don't think he should?

GINGRICH: I think that it is less powerful than winning this fight. He's got to decide what he wants to do. But I always tell people, when you start thinking about any kind of campaign -- military, political -- you always have to say then what. Ok?

Tomorrow morning he declares a national emergency. It goes to court immediately. But nonetheless, we're moving in the right direction. He can't really declare victory over the Congress. I mean at that point what he's done is had a clever detour to get around the congress and that's not going to solve the long-term problem.

The long-term problem is Nancy Pelosi who has a crazy wing of her party now, a wing which is totally out of touch with reality. Nancy Pelosi right now thinks that she is the equal to the President.

I went through this. And we won and ultimately got a very important agreement with President Clinton because we had a principled positive goal. Nancy Pelosi's goal is purely negative.

Our goal was to get to a balanced budget which as you know, Steve, we were the only people in your lifetime to produce four consecutive balanced budgets. And that came out of having what was tied today as the longest shutdown in history. You don't do these things lightly.

FORBES: -- which just quickly, Mr. Speaker, gets to another thing. The Democrats are talking about a 70 percent tax rate and all that kind of thing. When are the Republicans going to put something exciting on the table and go on offense, like a flat tax, put something exciting out there for the American people instead of letting the Democrats dominate the agenda on taxes?

GINGRICH: Well, I hope they'll do it pretty quickly. Although I must say, if you want to think about a suicidal party, being the party that runs next year vote for me and I'll raise your taxes to 70 percent, I don't see how a New Yorker survives that. I hope every successful person in New York is looking at what the left wing of the party wants to do to them.

Because as you know, when you combine state, city and federal taxes, a 70 percent rate just would be a killer.

MCDOWELL: And the congresswoman who threw that idea out there, how many days had she been an actual member of Congress. And they put her on "60 Minutes" for Pete's sake but that's another problem.

The government shutdown reaching day 21, Newt -- Mr. Speaker -- which in day 21, that ties the '95, '96 government shutdown under the Clinton administration. You remember this well. You were speaker -- you were just talking about it. You were speaker during the shutdown.

It was -- if you look back, though, do you have any regrets about what happened back then?

GINGRICH: No. And I think the Washington establishment is just totally wrong about this. We were the first Republican congress in 40 years. We had a position we believed in deeply. We were prepared to fight over it. The reward was in 1996 we became the first Republican House reelected since 1928.

I mean all these so-called Washington smart people go around and say boy, that really hurt the Republicans. We're the first people that got reelected in 68 years. And it's because our base believed that we're real, that we were committed to welfare reform. We're committed to the largest capital gains tax cut in history. We're committed to balancing the budget.

The President has the same thing going for him. I mean he has communicated he's a man of strength. He's a man of determination. He is committed to protecting Americans and I think every day that this goes on, the Democrats are in danger of looking like a party that doesn't care about American lives, doesn't care about American families, and is frankly the party of illegal immigration rather than protecting Americans.

MCDOWELL: I want to get your reaction to Senator Kamala Harris who dismissed President Trump's border wall fight when she was on the late show with Stephen Colbert. Listen to this.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

SENATOR KAMALA HARRIS (D), CALIFORNIA: We have hundreds of thousands of Americans who are not going to get paid and they're not getting paid because the President of the United States has a vanity project that he doesn't want to give up. And it is outrageous. It is irresponsible.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCDOWELL: Vanity project, Mr. Speaker.

GINGRICH: Look, Kamala Harris represents what I think of as California crazy. I mean California's a state and the governor in California just said we're not only going to be a sanctuary state, we're going to have free healthcare for everybody and the governor of California, the new governor said and "I specifically mean illegal immigrants".

So he's sending a signal to the entire planet, if you can get to California, we'll take care of your health problems for free.

That is the kind of policies -- the former mayor of San Francisco, a city which now has people in hazmat suits paid $200,000 a year to walk around all day and pick up human feces off the street because there are so many homeless people in San Francisco which is by the way the largest center of capital in the world in the last 25 or 30 years.

So you have a state which is nuts. You have a senator who has no clue. And you have a governor who is saying basically I'd like to have open borders, be a sanctuary state and everybody who gets here, I will give them a taxpayers cost-free healthcare which, of course, will destroy the California health system.

I mean I just think there's a certain amount of craziness going on in California and Kamala Harris is just part of it.

MCDOWELL: So I'm putting you down as a no, you're not moving to California.

GINGRICH: I love California as a state. I just think its politicians have gone crazy. The state's wonderful.

MCDOWELL: the people are lovely. The state is beautiful. But it's a whole lot of crazy. Mr. Speaker -- thank you so much. Newt Gingrich -- great insight.

GINGRICH: Thank you.

MCDOWELL: And I want to bring you this. President Trump's tweet on the wall of the border, "I often said during rallies with little variation that Mexico will pay for the wall. We have just signed a great new trade deal with Mexico. It is billions of dollars a year. Better than the very bad NAFTA deal which it replaces. The difference pays for the wall many times over.

There's an issue there, though. That has to get ratified by Congress. Nancy Pelosi, now the new speaker, has to take it up. Will she just put it in her drawer and say bye-bye?

It's another worry for the markets that we haven't even talked about but we will as the show moves on.

Coming up, Apple rolling out new gear -- the tech giant unveiling three new iPhone models this year despite slumping sales. That story.

Plus parents of young children know this song well, "Baby Shark" swims into the history books.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MCDOWELL: U.S. troops have begun withdrawing from Syria.

Cheryl Casone has the details. Hey -- Cheryl.

CHERYL CASONE, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK CORRESPONDENT: Hey -- Dagen. Yes.

A U.S. Defense official has now confirmed to Fox News that those troops are being withdrawn on President Trump's orders to pull out of the country. Military officials aren't sharing an exact time line or locations of the troops, of course, for their safety. But the full withdrawal that President Trump is calling for overall may be a bit delayed.

U.S. National security advisor John Bolton said earlier this week that troops won't be pulled out until ISIS is completely defeated and Kurdish fighters are guaranteed protection from Turkey.

Well, more trouble for Huawei. The "Wall Street Journal" says an executive for the Chinese telecom company has been arrested in Poland and charged with espionage. The suspect is Huawei's local sales director who is a Chinese national. The former deputy head of Poland's IT Security Department also is in custody, we should add. This latest arrests coming amid concerns by the U.S. and other western governments that Beijing is using Huawei, the company, to spy on those countries.

Well, Apple reportedly is planning to introduce three new LCD iPhones this fall, despite the struggling 10R sales. And yes, I said iPhones.

The "Wall Street Journal" is reporting that Apple is going to unveil new camera features including a triple rear camera for the highest end model. Apple is sticking with LCD this year. But it's considering dropping its LCD models next year.

AlphaOne Capital Partners' founding partner Dan Niles was on MORNINGS WITH MARIA earlier this week. He said Apple is focusing on the wrong products.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

MARIA BARTIROMO, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: 5G is a really big deal. If 5G is on the horizon and I know that want to get the latest, greatest on my phone, but an iPhone is not compatible to 5G, why would I buy an iPhone?

DAN NILES, FOUNDING PARTNER, ALPHAONE CAPITAL: That's a really good point. And so I think when you think about 2019, 5G is going to roll out -- it's going to start rolling out to their carriers in the June quarter.

Well, Apple doesn't have a 5G phone out. So if you're trying to convince somebody hey, you want to spend $1,000. Well, does it have 5G? Well no. So then they'll wait.

So I think this year could actually be worse than last year in terms of how much the smartphone market shrinks. Apple not having 5G is an even bigger problem.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

CASONE: All right. Let's take a look at shares of Apple in the premarket, unchanged right now -- Dagen. And you know, you've also led some great discussions this week on Apple -- Dagen, in particular, how many $1,000 phones do consumers need?

MCDOWELL: Exactly. And Apple is upping the amount of money that you get on a trade-in, trying to get people to -- to get people into these phones.

Thank you so much -- Cheryl.

CASONE: You bet.

MCDOWELL: Lindsey -- I want to get your reaction to something because it's not just Apple. And we're going to talk about it later in the show but the retail. Macy's stock had its worst one day performance ever I think yesterday on weak sales. So again, that was hard on the markets, hard on that sector, for sure.

LINDSEY BELL, INVESTMENT STRATEGIST, CFRA: For sure. And you know what, I think what surprised me the most is that the conversation yesterday was about the consumer being dense (ph). Not about what was really plaguing retail at the end of third quarter earnings was what about trade and how is that going to impact the cost of goods and things, apparel and things that they're selling.

I think that this is going to be -- still be a very good holiday sales season, like the Mastercard numbers you got as well as some of the other data we're seeing in retail sales is going to show that there are winners and losers within the retail space. And I think Amazon and Walmart are going to be some of the biggest winners.

MCDOWELL: Right. Elle Brands which is the owner of Victoria's secret also was down about 5 percent yesterday -- tepid holiday sales. This is a front page story in the "Wall Street Journal" which we warned you about because again, women are not buying that garbage that is like some standard of beauty that nobody is not related to anybody's life anymore. And they keep just pushing ahead with this thing from the early '90s.

You've got be innovative, you've got to be doing e-commerce right. That's where you're going to win.

MCDOWELL: Thank you so much. And I will get your response to Speaker Gingrich. I want to know because --

WOLF: I'm going to wait until we have him back on.

MCDOWELL: Well, you can't. I'm going to make you talk about it.

Coming up, markets on a winning streak -- we're looking at stocks and how the government shutdown is impacting the IPO market in the New Year.

And social media's impact, one study finding heavy Facebook use could be impairing your decision making. Details ahead.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MCDOWELL: The government shutdown now tied for the longest in the nation's history. Tomorrow it will be the longest if it lasts. And it could delay IPOs in 2019 in the New Year.

Joining us now, PWC partner, head of financial services Neil Dhar. Neal -- great of you to be here.

NEIL DHAR, PWC PARTNER: Thanks for having me.

MCDOWELL: What's the impact right now?

DHAR: Right now it's very difficult to get an IPO out in the marketplace because you need a regulator to sort of sign off on the document. There is no regulator at the moment other than emergency things. So what we're seeing is December had a lot of volatility in the marketplace. So it was very slow from an IPO standpoint.

And now, we're not going to see many things, basically what happens in January is if you don't get IPOs out immediately, then folks will wait for year-end earnings.

MCDOWELL: So isn't this is a blessing for these companies, though, in some way? Because it gives them cover. Kathleen smith, who researches wait for year-end earnings.

MCDOWELL: So isn't this is a blessing for these companies, though, in some way? Because it gives them cover. Because Kathleen Smith, who researches IPOs, was on this program and she thought the market was so rotten at the end of the year that it could be closed for IPOs at least in the first quarter so it gives them a little bit of cover to take some time and wait for the market to recover. Do you agree with that?

DHAR: Well, I think 2018 was a very good year for IPOs. There was about 215 IPOs which is actually a very good year. Usually anything over 200 we believe is a strong year.

So we have that momentum. You're right, things did slow down at the back end of the year. Volatility is usually a very big pain point in the unless you get into

MCDOWELL: She was really talking about the performance in the second half of the year, the companies that did go public.

DHAR: We did see that. We did see a drop in relation to the IPOs that went out at the beginning of the year, traded up versus the one that's came out at the back end.

FORBES: And Neil -- I think what you said, volatility is the key point. We have volatility with the government shutdown, with geopolitical risk, with trade, with tax 1.0 versus 2.0, with fiscal, with fed. And a company -- we can live on good and/or bad news. But what we struggle with is when we have no idea what the future may be --

DHAR: Yes.

FORBES: -- which is why this government shutdown. The idea that we have regulators not able to work. We have the FDA not able to work. These impact all companies, whether it's going into earnings season or it's going into IPO season or it's going into retail sales. You know, are we going to get the right numbers?

So what do you tell your customers how to deal with this whole volatile situation?

DHAR: There's certain things you can control, certain things you can't. So what we see from an IPO to be strong in the marketplace, good management, strong growth, strong cash flows -- that's what they can control from a story standpoint.

The other stuff, you have to be ready and one of the things that we preach as we help our clients think through this stuff is you've to be ready.

An IPO is about a nine to 12-month process to get ready. And you never know what's going to happen in a marketplace and when you could actually dip in into the market place in a favorable moment.

BELL: Can I just ask one question though on IPOs? 81 percent -- I saw a stat from the University of Florida this year were unprofitable companies. That rivals 2000 when we were in the dot-com bubble. So what does that signal about where we are in the cycle of IPOs or maybe even in the business cycle.

DHAR: Well, we've seen -- IPOs come in a lot of different flavors. You have cash stable companies, a lot of the sponsor backed companies are actually cash stable companies. We have seen a big uptick in relation to get tech and pharma life sciences IPOs.

And those companies will have that type of profile, strong revenue growth, but potentially loss-making type of companies.

MCDOWELL: At least it doesn't smack of the same type of companies that were going public back in 2000, companies that just seemed really ridiculous that barely had a business plan.

I don't think that -- at least I don't get the same sensation.

DHAR: And there's a lot more diligence in relation to what the investors are asking for, what companies are being asked on the road shows, the level of diligence feels different.

FORBES: I agree.

MCDOWELL: Neil it's good to see you. I've lived through -- thank God I lived through that.

Neil Dhar -- Good to see you.

DHAR: Thanks again.

MCDOWELL: Coming up taking on big technology, our next guest says that customers and congress need to stand up to some of the biggest companies in the world.

Plus, baby shark attack.

(MUSIC)

MCDOWELL: The YouTube children's song, now a historical success. The story has parents everywhere bopping and shaking their heads.

We make Steve Forbes sing it, coming up.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Welcome back. I'm Dagen McDowell in for Maria Bartiromo. It's Friday, January 11th. Your top stories at 07:30 a.m. Eastern.

The shutdown showdown enters day 21. Now tied for the longest in U.S. history. President Trump considering declaring a national emergency and using disaster aid to fund the border wall.

Futures are heading lower this morning, ever so slight. Tough to make the connection between the shutdown and the markets at this point because we've had a great run. We've got a 20 point loss on the Dow Futures right now. The major markets gauges gained about half of one percent yesterday and they're on track for their longest winning streak since early October, but really before that massive selloff at the end of the year.

In Europe we have some selling to report in England, France and Germany, although slight, losses of about half of one percent in France and Germany at the moment.

Asia markets, different story, finishing higher overnight, all four there.

Recall alert, FiatChrysler warning of a potentially dangerous flaw impacting 1.6 million vehicles but there's an even bigger issue. We have the details.

Then addicted to Facebook, we'll tell you about new research that says using the social media app could be as bad as a cocaine addiction.

And shark attack, the hit song baby shark making history.

To our top story this half hour, taking on technology. Companies like Facebook and Google are bigger than ever. In fact, the number of Facebook users now exceeds the populations of China, the United States and Brazil combined. Google oversees 90 percent of all online searches. Between those two companies, they control roughly two-thirds of all advertising online.

My next guest says there more has to be done to rein these companies in. She has an op-ed in the San Francisco Chronicle, consumers, congress: stand up to tech giants, saying this. When a small cadre of companies begins to operate as retailers, news aggregators, advertising platforms and information keepers, they don't just rise to the top of the marketplace, they become the marketplace. Walling off competition in a way that threatens the very idea of consumer choice.

Joining me now, consumer reports president and CEO, Marta Tellado. Good to see you Marta this morning.

MARTA TELLADO, PRESIDENT & CEO, CONSUMER REPORTS: Great to be here, Dagen.

MCDOWELL: What do you mean by this op-ed? What should consumers do? What should Congress do?

TELLADO: Well, think about it. Our founders were great believers in the free market and competition but the thing about free market, you also need free choice. How do consumers have free choice when they don't have knowledge or transparency about what's in the marketplace? So we need transparency. We need accountability. We also need some changes. The physics of this new reality are very different.

So, we don't really have the rules and regulations in place to even think and contemplate how to hold these companies accountable.

MCDOWELL: When you say rules and regulations, though, Steve's neck turns bright red. But Steve, do you -- what do you have to say to Marta's editorial?

STEVE FORBES, CHAIRMAN, FORBES MEDIA: Well, in terms of regulations, I think again, you're going to get national regulations if only because states are starting to do crazy things. You don't want to vulcanized market which would hurt everybody. So I think it's a preemption. You will get something national.

But in terms of -- in terms of getting information out there, it's as open as it's ever been before. What I want to ask you is, we said the same thing about IBM, said the same thing about Microsoft, said the same thing about Walmart, Amazon, now we say about Amazon. Aren't there things they're going out there that are going to upend these people like 5G or new technologies that are going to undo them like they've always done before?

TELLADO: Here's the difference, I think it's yes, we have seen behavior like this before. We haven't quite seen so few companies like big tech that are controlling so much. As I said in the op-ed, they're not just tech companies, they are ad platforms. They are retailers. They are controlling our experience.

So the dynamic, it's not just what we've seen before. The physics of this are entirely different. It's too few of them and not enough transparency for consumers to make decisions and --

FORBES: Do you think block chain technology, have you look at that as a way of getting our privacy back?

TELLADO: People are talking about block chain technology, Bitcoin. Those things are thought about, talked about, they're not a reality for everyday consumers.

MCDOWELL: What about personal choice, Aurora? I know you want to get in here. But again, if consumers just turn their backs on some of these companies in a way, it's different if you talk about the way that ads are served online and that's tougher. But in terms of Facebook, people could just stop using the platform and really pull back and maybe that would give rise to alternatives who would be -- with companies that would be more transparent. But that just seems like a really long road ahead.

TELLADO: I think you're seeing that already and particularly with young audiences turning away from Facebook. But the choices are not there and the information they need, these companies are not being transparent about the information they're using. Consumers are really being victimized by these incredible technologies that are delighting us but they're also limiting our choice in terms of pricing, in terms of the whole experience that we have in our daily lives.

ROBERT WOLF, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR: So Marta, you know, it's a bit of a double edged sword because I love what you wrote. But we applaud the shared services economy because it makes it, one, more efficient for us all. Two, actually pricing has gone down, not up in the shared services economy. So, in a consumer driven country like ours which is 73 percent consumer driven to the head of consumer -- to your company, that's a good thing.

TELLADO: Yes.

WOLF: Now, on the flip side, I agree with you on the regulation side. Because isn't Facebook and these companies, shouldn't they be regulated no different than the Wall Street Journal and Fox because really they dominate advertising, they dominate -- you know, eyeballs. And I think that's what you're saying, that there has to be a level playing field for what I would say is the more mature companies or the older school companies that are innovating maybe at the same pace, but they don't yet have a oligopoly and monopoly (INAUDIBLE).

MCDOWELL: And to that point, Congress could remove the liability waiver that these social media companies have. They have a liability waiver for user generated content because they say they're not media companies. So, that is something that Congress could do, but go ahead.

TELLADO: But let me get to something you said, Robert, and that is about price and quality. Yes, we're seeing great stuff there. What we're not seeing -- we're seeing price and quality. But what about privacy and security? I don't think that things on the books today even come close to addressing that.

WOLF: Well that's why I'm a supporter of block chain protocol. I think it's going to -- I think it's going to proliferate a lot faster than the marketplace.

TELLADO: And we're anxious to see that. But in -- but in the meantime, what are the standards by which consumers can go into the marketplace and make choices about products were in privacy and security and there aren't. And which is what -- that's caused us to innovate as well. So what we're doing is we have developed a whole series of tests and protocols so that consumers can actually make a choice about which period -- payment app is going to be the safest for them, and that's exactly what we did.

And guess what, as soon as we started testing and creating these standards, companies started competing against them and saying we want to be number one, we want to have the best smart T.V. that protects your privacy.

MCDOWELL: Right.

TELLADO: So, there are ways to incentivize. It's not all just regulation.

MCDOWELL: The problem is that you touch on, is that there is all the power is in a few hands. You talk about millennials leaving Facebook. Well, they're using Instagram which Facebook owns.

TELLADO: Correct.

MCDOWELL: I never understood why that was allowed to happen. Again, these nerd robber barons who are controlling all of our information and tracking everything that we do.

TELLADO: Well, I think what all these companies are really excelling at in addition to delighting us is being consumer trust busters. I mean, consumer trust right now is at an all-time low.

MCDOWELL: Marta, great to see you. Tellado, did I say it right?

TELLADO: You did indeed.

MCDOWELL: OK, great. That was very important to me. Marta, great to see you. Thank you so much.

TELLADO: Great to be here, thank you so much.

MCDOWELL: Here's our highlight reel from this week. Must see moments from the show.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

SARAH HUCKABEE SANDERS, WHITE HOUSE PRESS SECRETARY: The president doesn't want a government shutdown. He wants the government to open, but he also wants it to do its job.

JAMIE DIMON, CHAIRMAN AND CEO, J.P. MORGAN CHASE: The shutdown is not good. But my bigger complaint is that America may be because of bipartisan politics has been unable to do a lot of things that need to be done. If your one of those folks out there, you're a J.P. Morgan Chase client, we're going to help you. Call in and we're going to get you some help deferring payments.

MARIA BARTIROMO, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: How long can the credit markets stay this tight before you actually do see it as a worry sign?

DIMON: For a while. I'm really not worried about it. I think -- I think you're just having -- if you look at it the other way around, credit spreads were abnormally low for a long time. This is more maybe a little bit of a normalization. And you know, you and I both know that the tip of the ice -- the tip of the spear is IPOs and high yield. So when people -- when sentiment changes dramatically those are usually the first two areas where people cut back and then they kind of open up over time.

MOHAMED EL-ERIAN, CHIEF ECONOMIC ADVISOR, ALLIANZ: In 12 months we've gone from the hope of synchronized pick up in global growth with everybody doing better to divergence with the U.S. outpacing Europe and China. And now, we're worried about the wrong type of convergence. We're worried about the U.S. slowing to the rest of the world instead of the rest of the world picking up towards us.

It's for the Fed to realize that it can't be on auto pilot. That it has to be more sensitive to what's happening not just in the U.S. economy, but also to what's happening globally.

DAN NILES, FOUNDING PARTNER, ALPHAONE CAPITAL PARTNERS: Not sure Apple realizes the real issue is that they're trying to sell a Ferrari in the market that can afford a Ford. This is why Apple's been losing market shares. They actually went from the second largest vendor of phones in the world, Huawei passed them out of China to become the second largest.

KEN FRAZIER, CEO, MERCK: We want to work with the administration and Congress, both parties to ensure that patients can have meaningful access to drugs and affordability is a real problem. The question is, how do we solve the affordability problem for today's patients. We've shown already that Keytruda as immunotherapy and in combination with chemotherapy can significantly reduce the amount of deaths. So, with respect to newly diagnosed people with the most common form of lung cancer called non squamous lung cancer we're able to reduce the death rate by 51 percent. There's never been anything like that.

MERCEDES COLWIN, FOX NEWS CHANNEL LEGAL ANALYST: Started Amazon during their marriage, dollar for dollar it was amassed during that marriage, right down the middle, 50 percent generally would go to the spouse. Anything that he comes out with a statement that can impact the shares of stock and the value of it can result in a shareholder derivative suit.

BARTIROMO: Harley Davidson unveiling a new motorcycle later this year. Joining us right now is Harley Davidson chief marketing officer Heather Malenshek.

HEATHER MALENSHEK, CHIEF MARKETING OFFICER, HARLEY DAVIDSON: As we think about -- I mean, electric vehicles they're becoming much more mainstream but two-wheel mobility -- electric two-wheel mobility is relatively new trend and we are setting out to lead the electrification of motorcycling. So, this is all part of our More Roads plan that we launched last year, which was around broader access to the brands, so opening up new markets and new channels.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MCDOWELL: President Trump continues to tweet this morning. H1B holders, he's talking about visas. H1B holders in the United States can rest assured that changes are soon coming which will bring both simplicity and certainty to your stay including a potential path to citizenship. We want to encourage talented and highly skilled people to pursue career options in the U.S. That's a biggy -- that is a biggy -- that is --

FORBES: That may lay the basis for resolving this crisis because it gives something that California H1B visas have been severely restricted. You start to throw that out there, along with DACA, you've got a deal.

MCDOWELL: Steve drops the mic. FiatChrysler meantime issuing a major recall over potentially dangerous flaws. Cheryl Casone has the details that you need to know, Cheryl.

CHERYL CASONE, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Yes, this is interesting, Dagen. FiatChrysler recalling more than 1.6 million vehicles worldwide to replace Takata airbags. These airbags can explode with too much force and send shrapnel flying. The affected models include the 2010 through 2016 Jeep Wrangler and the 2010 Ram pickup. This is the third recall over Takata airbags just this week alone. At the recalls by Toyota and Ford. And Takata as you know, it's been in the news for years over airbag troubles. Chrysler, the stock down 28 percent from one year ago.

Well, a new study finding that heavy Facebook users make impaired decisions like similar to drug addicts basically. Researchers tested about 70 participants with an exercise. Psychologist used to measure decision making. Based on the people who admitted being excessive Facebook users did worse on the test than those who didn't use Facebook as often. Shares of Facebook are lower in the premarket, down more than half a percent.

And then finally, parents of young children, you should be so excited because the song baby shark has become a smash hit with little kids and now it is on this week's billboard hot 100.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

Baby shark, doo doo doo doo doo doo. Baby shark, doo doo doo doo doo doo. Baby shark, doo doo doo doo doo doo. Baby shark!

(END VIDEO CLIP)

CASONE: This music video has racked up more than 2.1 billion views on YouTube. The song has actually been around since 2015. But it got popular last week -- last year, excuse me, when a social media challenge asked listeners to record themselves doing this is the baby shark dance. So yes, if you have young kids at home, you thought frozen was bad mom and dad, get ready for baby shark, I know.

MCDOWELL: It's Steve, baby shark doo doo doo doo doo doo. Steve's doing it. I'm going to be doing that all day long.

FORBES: We've got two young grandchildren, three and-a-half and one and-a- half, and the only way they eat food is you have that device in front of them playing baby shark. We sing along with them. They eat the food. It's great.

MCDOWELL: That was helpful hints from grandfather Steve Forbes.

FORBES: Meet all needs here. Markets, parenting, babies.

MCDOWELL: Yes, we address -- we address everyone's needs, absolutely.

Coming up, healthy food for man's best friend. We talk to one company that wants your dog eating as well as you, next.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MCDOWELL: Delicious, delectable, high end dog food, a new personalized pet meal start-up called The Farmer's Dog boasts that meals are made -- freshly made and healthy even humans can eat them and they're delivered to your door.

Joining me now, the co-founders of The Farmer's Dog Brett Podolsky and Jonathan Regev. Jonathan and good to see you both. And Brett, to you first.

BRETT PODOLSKY, CO-FOUNDER, THE FARMER'S DOG: Sure.

MCDOWELL: So, I'm going to hold up this delicious bowl of -- it looks like tuna and corn, and broccoli and squash and carrots. So this is not just for people but for your dog.

JONATHAN REGEV, CO-FOUNDER, THE FARMER'S DOG: Yes, it's for your dog. It's actually turkey.

MCDOWELL: Turkey. It looks delicious. But how did you guys come up with the idea for the -- for the company?

PODOLSKY: Well, it all started with my dog, Jada. She was sick for the first two years that I had her. I was desperate to find the solution for her. And after trying every pet food and going to several vets, finally a vet recommended that I tried home cooking for her and it was like magic, all of her symptoms disappeared.

And it made me wonder what was going on with pet food because I used -- the vet recommended that I use the exact same ingredients that were on the pet food label that I had been feeding her. But when I cooked it, the result was very different. It wasn't brown balls, it looked like actual food. And her stomach symptoms were cured.

So, I wanted something better for her. And after doing a lot of research into the pet industry and for anybody that has done any research into how they make pet food, it's pretty alarming. So, I wanted something better for her. And after realizing there was just no companies out there that I felt comfortable feeding her, we decided to build that company.

MCDOWELL: Well, how did you build the company, Jonathan? How did you -- how are you getting this message out to consumers who might just be ordering their dog food from Amazon?

REGEV: Sure, yes. So, at first, we really didn't focus on marketing. It was really difficult and complicated to create the supply chain needed. And also, the technology to create a subscription to have food look like this.

Because remember, this food in particular, it's not meant to look pretty. And it's not meant to look fancy. It's just -- you know, fresh food.

MCDOWELL: Well, it does look fresh -- it does look fresh.

REGEV: And it is fresh. And so that -- to do that in an affordable way and also to make the food very convenient to feed, that was where the difficulty was. So, we really didn't focus on marketing for the first three years or so. It really grew by word of mouth.

MCDOWELL: So, how are you selling it? Brett, how is -- how are -- is the dog food sold essentially? Like, do you advertise on podcasts? It's direct to consumer? Are you in stores at all?

REGEV: Yes, so we're just -- we're just starting to now. So, it's online only and it's direct to consumer. Because direct to consumer is the really -- the only way that we could keep the food fresh and convenient.

So, basically how that works is you go online, you enter your dog's information. And we take all of that into account. We create a custom plan for them and then that feeds back into our very complicated supply chain that can then deliver the food fresh. So food actually comes in this package, right, so it's personalized for your dog.

MCDOWELL: You can hand it to me.

REGEV: Sure.

MCDOWELL: Thanks.

REGEV: So, it's pre-portioned for your dog. Your dog's name will be on it. And that's -- thank you, you're very good. And that's mainly so we know exactly how much you have at any given time, right? And so, before you run out, our kitchens are making food.

FORBES: (INAUDIBLE) Starbucks for dogs.

MCDOWELL: Right, exactly.

FORBES: Bring your dog and you get high end foods at Starbucks.

REGEV: Dogs should be allowed at any cafe.

MCDOWELL: I agree. And you're welcome back on that note, Jonathan and Brett.

REGEV: Thank you.

MCDOWELL: Please come back both of you.

REGEV: Appreciate it.

MCDOWELL: We'll be right back, everybody.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

END

END

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5W9V-1SM1-JBHT-D29N-00000-00Standing Up to Tech Giants; Fiat Chrysler Automobiles Recalls 1.6 Million Vehicles; Heavy Facebook User Danger; High-End Dog Food Delivery Boasts Food Produced to Human Standards2019-01-11T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:26:46ZLexisNexisStanding Up to Tech Giants; FiatChrysler Automobiles Recalls 1.6 Million Vehicles; Heavy Facebook User Danger; High-End Dog Food Delivery Boasts Food Produced to Human StandardsLanhamFULL TEXT

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Good morning. I'm Dagen McDowell, in for Maria Bartiromo. It's Friday, January 11th.

Your top stories at 7:00 a.m. Eastern.

The shutdown entering day 21. Tied for the longest in U.S. history. President Trump now considering declaring a national emergency and using disaster aid money to fund the border wall.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: My sacred duty, most sacred duty as president is to defend the people of our nation. That's whether it's from foreign nations or along the border. It's all defending our people. And defending them properly and strongly and really rightly, justly.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCDOWELL: Meantime futures are showing this this morning. 29 point loss, 30 point loss on the DOW futures. Investors are waiting for some headway, like some evidence that a trade deal is coming together with China, although optimistic about the progress so far.

Yesterday all three of the major market gauges gained about half of 1 percent, markets on their longest winning streak since early October.

In Europe, we have some losses to report across the board, in England, France and Germany, although slight there.

And your Asian markets -- all four major Asian markets finishing higher overnight.

Oil heading to the plus side this morning. The price of crude oil on its longest upward swing since January of 2010.

Plus, Hail Mary, details on Apple's plan for a new phone that the company hopes will pull it out of that iPhone sales slump.

And shark attack, the hit song, "Baby Shark", makes history. We will bury it in your head and you will not be able to get rid of it.

Here with me to break it all down -- CFRA investment strategist, Lindsey Bell; Forbes Media chairman and former Republican presidential candidate, Steve Forbes; and Fox News contributor, 32Advisors founder and CEO, former economic advisor to President Obama -- Robert Wolf. Welcome one and all.

ROBERT WOLF, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR: Great first hour.

MCDOWELL: You're such a flatterer.

WOLF: Great first hour.

MCDOWELL: Because you're here and you're here and you're here.

Somebody already called me a nasty name on Twitter. But I'll take that. That's fine.

STEVE FORBES, FORBES MEDIA CHAIRMAN: Just think of that shark song. It works with three-year-olds and one-year-olds.

MCDOWELL: Do you know the song -- Steve?

FORBES: I'm not going to hurt your ratings by citing it but my three-year- old can cite it.

MCDOWELL: I just love that -- deeply and profoundly. So we'll get to that later this hour.

But right now our top story -- weighing a national emergency, White House aides exploring new options to fund a southern border wall as lawmakers remain at a standstill over any deal. The White House directing the Army Corps of Engineers to divert money from other areas like disaster relief projects to secure funding if necessary.

President Trump told Sean Hannity on Fox News that a border wall is the only solution.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

TRUMP: It's common sense. It really is, when you think of it, whether you're into the world of law enforcement like these incredible folks behind us (AUDIO GAP) so easily. I mean it would make their job so much better. And they could also go to other areas because we have the wall, you don't need so many people. We would probably pay for that many times in one year.

The law is very clear. I mean we have the absolute right to declare a national emergency. And this is security stuff. This is a national emergency.

If you don't have a barrier, whether it's a steel barrier or a concrete wall, substantial and strong, you are never going to solve this problem. You're never going to solve it.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCDOWELL: Joining us now Fox News contributor, former speaker of the house and author of "Trump's America", Newt Gingrich.

Mr. Speaker -- it's always a pleasure to see you. I am dying to hear what you have to say about this. What do you say about the President potentially using emergency authority to get this wall built?

NEWT GINGRICH, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR: Well, I mean if the lawyers tell him that it will withstand a court challenge, he has every right to do it. He's commander in chief and the Congress has allocated money for the defense of the United States.

But I do think that there's a certain value to him fighting this out. Every day that goes by, it's more obvious that the Democrats don't value the safety of Americans nearly as much as they value the convenience of people trying to get here illegally.

And every day that goes by I think the fact that the Democrats won't compromise, you know, Nancy Pelosi saying if you give me everything I want, I still won't give you the wall. I think that attitude is a really bad way for them to start with a new Congress.

And so I think in many ways this is a key moment for the President in defining what's at stake for the country and in shaping the next two years.

MCDOWELL: Will the Republicans continue to stand with him? That's what -- in terms of will their knees buckle or do they have -- do they have the guts --

GINGRICH: It doesn't matter.

MCDOWELL: -- to stand with him?

GINGRICH: It doesn't matter. If he's prepared to veto a bill, he's certainly going to keep one-third plus one of the Senate and one-third plus one of the House, so he'll sustain any veto he wants. If some Republicans at the margin want to be timid, they want to be panicked, they want to run in circles, you know, the way our constitutional system works, a president who is tough and determined has enormous advantages.

And I think that he in many ways can relax and just say -- you know, first of all, Senator McConnell said he won't bring up a bill the President won't sign. So it's not going to go through the Senate.

Nancy Pelosi can -- you know, she can perform a ballet act, she can dance in circles, she can jump up and down, she would have gymnast -- it won't matter. It's not going to change anything. She can't force it through.

FORBES: Mr. Speaker, sounds like you don't think the President should declare a national emergency but simply let the thing play out. Is that what you're saying? You'd advise him not to do that? He's winning already, why mess it up?

GINGRICH: Well look, I think if you got -- I mean first of all, I think what he said all along is the right position. He is not going to sign this appropriation unless they solve --

(CROSSTALKING)

FORBES: But you don't think he should do the national emergency?

GINGRICH: -- commit themselves to solving it.

FORBES: You're saying he can't but you don't think he should?

GINGRICH: I think that it is less powerful than winning this fight. He's got to decide what he wants to do. But I always tell people, when you start thinking about any kind of campaign -- military, political -- you always have to say then what. Ok?

Tomorrow morning he declares a national emergency. It goes to court immediately. But nonetheless, we're moving in the right direction. He can't really declare victory over the Congress. (COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MCDOWELL: Delicious, delectable, high end dog food, a new personalized pet meal start-up called The Farmer's Dog boasts that meals are made -- freshly made and healthy even humans can eat them and they're delivered to your door.

Joining me now, the co-founders of The Farmer's Dog Brett Podolsky and Jonathan Regev. Jonathan and good to see you both. And Brett, to you first.

BRETT PODOLSKY, CO-FOUNDER, THE FARMER'S DOG: Sure.

MCDOWELL: So, I'm going to hold up this delicious bowl of -- it looks like tuna and corn, and broccoli and squash and carrots. So this is not just for people but for your dog.

JONATHAN REGEV, CO-FOUNDER, THE FARMER'S DOG: Yes, it's for your dog. It's actually turkey.

MCDOWELL: Turkey. It looks delicious. But how did you guys come up with the idea for the -- for the company?

PODOLSKY: Well, it all started with my dog, Jada. She was sick for the first two years that I had her. I was desperate to find the solution for her. And after trying every pet food and going to several vets, finally a vet recommended that I tried home cooking for her and it was like magic, all of her symptoms disappeared.

And it made me wonder what was going on with pet food because I used -- the vet recommended that I use the exact same ingredients that were on the pet food label that I had been feeding her. But when I cooked it, the result was very different. It wasn't brown balls, it looked like actual food. And her stomach symptoms were cured.

So, I wanted something better for her. And after doing a lot of research into the pet industry and for anybody that has done any research into how they make pet food, it's pretty alarming. So, I wanted something better for her. And after realizing there was just no companies out there that I felt comfortable feeding her, we decided to build that company.

MCDOWELL: Well, how did you build the company, Jonathan? How did you -- how are you getting this message out to consumers who might just be ordering their dog food from Amazon?

REGEV: Sure, yes. So, at first, we really didn't focus on marketing. It was really difficult and complicated to create the supply chain needed. And also, the technology to create a subscription to have food look like this.

Because remember, this food in particular, it's not meant to look pretty. And it's not meant to look fancy. It's just -- you know, fresh food.

MCDOWELL: Well, it does look fresh -- it does look fresh.

REGEV: And it is fresh. And so that -- to do that in an affordable way and also to make the food very convenient to feed, that was where the difficulty was. So, we really didn't focus on marketing for the first three years or so. It really grew by word of mouth.

MCDOWELL: So, how are you selling it? Brett, how is -- how are -- is the dog food sold essentially? Like, do you advertise on podcasts? It's direct to consumer? Are you in stores at all?

REGEV: Yes, so we're just -- we're just starting to now. So, it's online only and it's direct to consumer. Because direct to consumer is the really -- the only way that we could keep the food fresh and convenient.

So, basically how that works is you go online, you enter your dog's information. And we take all of that into account. We create a custom plan for them and then that feeds back into our very complicated supply chain that can then deliver the food fresh. So food actually comes in this package, right, so it's personalized for your dog.

MCDOWELL: You can hand it to me.

REGEV: Sure.

MCDOWELL: Thanks.

REGEV: So, it's pre-portioned for your dog. Your dog's name will be on it. And that's -- thank you, you're very good. And that's mainly so we know exactly how much you have at any given time, right? And so, before you run out, our kitchens are making food.

FORBES: (INAUDIBLE) Starbucks for dogs.

MCDOWELL: Right, exactly.

FORBES: Bring your dog and you get high end foods at Starbucks.

REGEV: Dogs should be allowed at any cafe.

MCDOWELL: I agree. And you're welcome back on that note, Jonathan and Brett.

REGEV: Thank you.

MCDOWELL: Please come back both of you.

REGEV: Appreciate it.

MCDOWELL: We'll be right back, everybody.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

END

END

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5W8B-G9S1-DY0W-43J7-00000-00Standing Up to Tech Giants; Fiat Chrysler Automobiles Recalls 1.6 Million Vehicles; Heavy Facebook User Danger; High-End Dog Food Delivery Boasts Food Produced to Human Standards2019-01-11T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:26:46ZLexisNexisStanding Up to Tech Giants; FiatChrysler Automobiles Recalls 1.6 Million Vehicles; Heavy Facebook User Danger; High-End Dog Food Delivery Boasts Food Produced to Human StandardsLanhamFULL TEXT

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Good morning. I'm Dagen McDowell, in for Maria Bartiromo. It's Friday, January 11th.

Your top stories at 7:00 a.m. Eastern.

The shutdown entering day 21. Tied for the longest in U.S. history. President Trump now considering declaring a national emergency and using disaster aid money to fund the border wall.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: My sacred duty, most sacred duty as president is to defend the people of our nation. That's whether it's from foreign nations or along the border. It's all defending our people. And defending them properly and strongly and really rightly, justly.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCDOWELL: Meantime futures are showing this this morning. 29 point loss, 30 point loss on the DOW futures. Investors are waiting for some headway, like some evidence that a trade deal is coming together with China, although optimistic about the progress so far.

Yesterday all three of the major market gauges gained about half of 1 percent, markets on their longest winning streak since early October.

In Europe, we have some losses to report across the board, in England, France and Germany, although slight there.

And your Asian markets -- all four major Asian markets finishing higher overnight.

Oil heading to the plus side this morning. The price of crude oil on its longest upward swing since January of 2010.

Plus, Hail Mary, details on Apple's plan for a new phone that the company hopes will pull it out of that iPhone sales slump.

And shark attack, the hit song, "Baby Shark", makes history. We will bury it in your head and you will not be able to get rid of it.

Here with me to break it all down -- CFRA investment strategist, Lindsey Bell; Forbes Media chairman and former Republican presidential candidate, Steve Forbes; and Fox News contributor, 32Advisors founder and CEO, former economic advisor to President Obama -- Robert Wolf. Welcome one and all.

ROBERT WOLF, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR: Great first hour.

MCDOWELL: You're such a flatterer.

WOLF: Great first hour.

MCDOWELL: Because you're here and you're here and you're here.

Somebody already called me a nasty name on Twitter. But I'll take that. That's fine.

STEVE FORBES, FORBES MEDIA CHAIRMAN: Just think of that shark song. It works with three-year-olds and one-year-olds.

MCDOWELL: Do you know the song -- Steve?

FORBES: I'm not going to hurt your ratings by citing it but my three-year- old can cite it.

MCDOWELL: I just love that -- deeply and profoundly. So we'll get to that later this hour.

But right now our top story -- weighing a national emergency, White House aides exploring new options to fund a southern border wall as lawmakers remain at a standstill over any deal. The White House directing the Army Corps of Engineers to divert money from other areas like disaster relief projects to secure funding if necessary.

President Trump told Sean Hannity on Fox News that a border wall is the only solution.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

TRUMP: It's common sense. It really is, when you think of it, whether you're into the world of law enforcement like these incredible folks behind us (AUDIO GAP) so easily. I mean it would make their job so much better. And they could also go to other areas because we have the wall, you don't need so many people. We would probably pay for that many times in one year.

The law is very clear. I mean we have the absolute right to declare a national emergency. And this is security stuff. This is a national emergency.

If you don't have a barrier, whether it's a steel barrier or a concrete wall, substantial and strong, you are never going to solve this problem. You're never going to solve it.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCDOWELL: Joining us now Fox News contributor, former speaker of the house and author of "Trump's America", Newt Gingrich.

Mr. Speaker -- it's always a pleasure to see you. I am dying to hear what you have to say about this. What do you say about the President potentially using emergency authority to get this wall built?

NEWT GINGRICH, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR: Well, I mean if the lawyers tell him that it will withstand a court challenge, he has every right to do it. He's commander in chief and the Congress has allocated money for the defense of the United States.

But I do think that there's a certain value to him fighting this out. Every day that goes by, it's more obvious that the Democrats don't value the safety of Americans nearly as much as they value the convenience of people trying to get here illegally.

And every day that goes by I think the fact that the Democrats won't compromise, you know, Nancy Pelosi saying if you give me everything I want, I still won't give you the wall. I think that attitude is a really bad way for them to start with a new Congress.

And so I think in many ways this is a key moment for the President in defining what's at stake for the country and in shaping the next two years.

MCDOWELL: Will the Republicans continue to stand with him? That's what -- in terms of will their knees buckle or do they have -- do they have the guts --

GINGRICH: It doesn't matter.

MCDOWELL: -- to stand with him?

GINGRICH: It doesn't matter. If he's prepared to veto a bill, he's certainly going to keep one-third plus one of the Senate and one-third plus one of the House, so he'll sustain any veto he wants. If some Republicans at the margin want to be timid, they want to be panicked, they want to run in circles, you know, the way our constitutional system works, a president who is tough and determined has enormous advantages.

And I think that he in many ways can relax and just say -- you know, first of all, Senator McConnell said he won't bring up a bill the President won't sign. So it's not going to go through the Senate.

Nancy Pelosi can -- you know, she can perform a ballet act, she can dance in circles, she can jump up and down, she would have gymnast -- it won't matter. It's not going to change anything. She can't force it through.

FORBES: Mr. Speaker, sounds like you don't think the President should declare a national emergency but simply let the thing play out. Is that what you're saying? You'd advise him not to do that? He's winning already, why mess it up?

GINGRICH: Well look, I think if you got -- I mean first of all, I think what he said all along is the right position. He is not going to sign this appropriation unless they solve --

(CROSSTALKING)

FORBES: But you don't think he should do the national emergency?

GINGRICH: -- commit themselves to solving it.

FORBES: You're saying he can't but you don't think he should?

GINGRICH: I think that it is less powerful than winning this fight. He's got to decide what he wants to do. But I always tell people, when you start thinking about any kind of campaign -- military, political -- you always have to say then what. Ok?

Tomorrow morning he declares a national emergency. It goes to court immediately. But nonetheless, we're moving in the right direction. He can't really declare victory over the Congress. I mean at that point what he's done is had a clever detour to get around the congress and that's not going to solve the long-term problem.

The long-term problem is Nancy Pelosi who has a crazy wing of her party now, a wing which is totally out of touch with reality. Nancy Pelosi right now thinks that she is the equal to the President.

I went through this. And we won and ultimately got a very important agreement with President Clinton because we had a principled positive goal. Nancy Pelosi's goal is purely negative.

Our goal was to get to a balanced budget which as you know, Steve, we were the only people in your lifetime to produce four consecutive balanced budgets. And that came out of having what was tied today as the longest shutdown in history. You don't do these things lightly.

FORBES: -- which just quickly, Mr. Speaker, gets to another thing. The Democrats are talking about a 70 percent tax rate and all that kind of thing. When are the Republicans going to put something exciting on the table and go on offense, like a flat tax, put something exciting out there for the American people instead of letting the Democrats dominate the agenda on taxes?

GINGRICH: Well, I hope they'll do it pretty quickly. Although I must say, if you want to think about a suicidal party, being the party that runs next year vote for me and I'll raise your taxes to 70 percent, I don't see how a New Yorker survives that. I hope every successful person in New York is looking at what the left wing of the party wants to do to them.

Because as you know, when you combine state, city and federal taxes, a 70 percent rate just would be a killer.

MCDOWELL: And the congresswoman who threw that idea out there, how many days had she been an actual member of Congress. And they put her on "60 Minutes" for Pete's sake but that's another problem.

The government shutdown reaching day 21, Newt -- Mr. Speaker -- which in day 21, that ties the '95, '96 government shutdown under the Clinton administration. You remember this well. You were speaker -- you were just talking about it. You were speaker during the shutdown.

It was -- if you look back, though, do you have any regrets about what happened back then?

GINGRICH: No. And I think the Washington establishment is just totally wrong about this. We were the first Republican congress in 40 years. We had a position we believed in deeply. We were prepared to fight over it. The reward was in 1996 we became the first Republican House reelected since 1928.

I mean all these so-called Washington smart people go around and say boy, that really hurt the Republicans. We're the first people that got reelected in 68 years. And it's because our base believed that we're real, that we were committed to welfare reform. We're committed to the largest capital gains tax cut in history. We're committed to balancing the budget.

The President has the same thing going for him. I mean he has communicated he's a man of strength. He's a man of determination. He is committed to protecting Americans and I think every day that this goes on, the Democrats are in danger of looking like a party that doesn't care about American lives, doesn't care about American families, and is frankly the party of illegal immigration rather than protecting Americans.

MCDOWELL: I want to get your reaction to Senator Kamala Harris who dismissed President Trump's border wall fight when she was on the late show with Stephen Colbert. Listen to this.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

SENATOR KAMALA HARRIS (D), CALIFORNIA: We have hundreds of thousands of Americans who are not going to get paid and they're not getting paid because the President of the United States has a vanity project that he doesn't want to give up. And it is outrageous. It is irresponsible.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCDOWELL: Vanity project, Mr. Speaker.

GINGRICH: Look, Kamala Harris represents what I think of as California crazy. I mean California's a state and the governor in California just said we're not only going to be a sanctuary state, we're going to have free healthcare for everybody and the governor of California, the new governor said and "I specifically mean illegal immigrants".

So he's sending a signal to the entire planet, if you can get to California, we'll take care of your health problems for free.

That is the kind of policies -- the former mayor of San Francisco, a city which now has people in hazmat suits paid $200,000 a year to walk around all day and pick up human feces off the street because there are so many homeless people in San Francisco which is by the way the largest center of capital in the world in the last 25 or 30 years.

So you have a state which is nuts. You have a senator who has no clue. And you have a governor who is saying basically I'd like to have open borders, be a sanctuary state and everybody who gets here, I will give them a taxpayers cost-free healthcare which, of course, will destroy the California health system.

I mean I just think there's a certain amount of craziness going on in California and Kamala Harris is just part of it.

MCDOWELL: So I'm putting you down as a no, you're not moving to California.

GINGRICH: I love California as a state. I just think its politicians have gone crazy. The state's wonderful.

MCDOWELL: the people are lovely. The state is beautiful. But it's a whole lot of crazy. Mr. Speaker -- thank you so much. Newt Gingrich -- great insight.

GINGRICH: Thank you.

MCDOWELL: And I want to bring you this. President Trump's tweet on the wall of the border, "I often said during rallies with little variation that Mexico will pay for the wall. We have just signed a great new trade deal with Mexico. It is billions of dollars a year. Better than the very bad NAFTA deal which it replaces. The difference pays for the wall many times over.

There's an issue there, though. That has to get ratified by Congress. Nancy Pelosi, now the new speaker, has to take it up. Will she just put it in her drawer and say bye-bye?

It's another worry for the markets that we haven't even talked about but we will as the show moves on.

Coming up, Apple rolling out new gear -- the tech giant unveiling three new iPhone models this year despite slumping sales. That story.

Plus parents of young children know this song well, "Baby Shark" swims into the history books.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MCDOWELL: U.S. troops have begun withdrawing from Syria.

Cheryl Casone has the details. Hey -- Cheryl.

CHERYL CASONE, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK CORRESPONDENT: Hey -- Dagen. Yes.

A U.S. Defense official has now confirmed to Fox News that those troops are being withdrawn on President Trump's orders to pull out of the country. Military officials aren't sharing an exact time line or locations of the troops, of course, for their safety. But the full withdrawal that President Trump is calling for overall may be a bit delayed.

U.S. National security advisor John Bolton said earlier this week that troops won't be pulled out until ISIS is completely defeated and Kurdish fighters are guaranteed protection from Turkey.

Well, more trouble for Huawei. The "Wall Street Journal" says an executive for the Chinese telecom company has been arrested in Poland and charged with espionage. The suspect is Huawei's local sales director who is a Chinese national. The former deputy head of Poland's IT Security Department also is in custody, we should add. This latest arrests coming amid concerns by the U.S. and other western governments that Beijing is using Huawei, the company, to spy on those countries.

Well, Apple reportedly is planning to introduce three new LCD iPhones this fall, despite the struggling 10R sales. And yes, I said iPhones.

The "Wall Street Journal" is reporting that Apple is going to unveil new camera features including a triple rear camera for the highest end model. Apple is sticking with LCD this year. But it's considering dropping its LCD models next year.

AlphaOne Capital Partners' founding partner Dan Niles was on MORNINGS WITH MARIA earlier this week. He said Apple is focusing on the wrong products.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

MARIA BARTIROMO, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: 5G is a really big deal. If 5G is on the horizon and I know that want to get the latest, greatest on my phone, but an iPhone is not compatible to 5G, why would I buy an iPhone?

DAN NILES, FOUNDING PARTNER, ALPHAONE CAPITAL: That's a really good point. And so I think when you think about 2019, 5G is going to roll out -- it's going to start rolling out to their carriers in the June quarter.

Well, Apple doesn't have a 5G phone out. So if you're trying to convince somebody hey, you want to spend $1,000. Well, does it have 5G? Well no. So then they'll wait.

So I think this year could actually be worse than last year in terms of how much the smartphone market shrinks. Apple not having 5G is an even bigger problem.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

CASONE: All right. Let's take a look at shares of Apple in the premarket, unchanged right now -- Dagen. And you know, you've also led some great discussions this week on Apple -- Dagen, in particular, how many $1,000 phones do consumers need?

MCDOWELL: Exactly. And Apple is upping the amount of money that you get on a trade-in, trying to get people to -- to get people into these phones.

Thank you so much -- Cheryl.

CASONE: You bet.

MCDOWELL: Lindsey -- I want to get your reaction to something because it's not just Apple. And we're going to talk about it later in the show but the retail. Macy's stock had its worst one day performance ever I think yesterday on weak sales. So again, that was hard on the markets, hard on that sector, for sure.

LINDSEY BELL, INVESTMENT STRATEGIST, CFRA: For sure. And you know what, I think what surprised me the most is that the conversation yesterday was about the consumer being dense (ph). Not about what was really plaguing retail at the end of third quarter earnings was what about trade and how is that going to impact the cost of goods and things, apparel and things that they're selling.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5W7D-09Y1-DXVP-V14S-00000-00Stand up to free speech peer pressure2019-05-30T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:26:46ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. A9Stand up to free speech peer pressureKyle Wingfield

Quick: Has America become a more or less open place for people to speak freely about their thoughts?

In terms of law and court precedents, speech has arguably never been freer. When it comes to voicing a contrary opinion on the most sensitive political and cultural topics, however, many of our tongues are tied and our fingers shy away from the keyboard.

Better not to say anything, we reason, than to deal with the blowback.

The answer to this speech-chilling political correctness is not a new law but personal courage, free speech attorney-turned-writer David French of the National Review Institute argued this past week in a speech in Atlanta.

“We’ve reached a position that is different from the classic defense of free speech in this country,” French said.

Rather than admitting none of us knows everything, and thus some humility is in order, too many Americans won’t accept they may need to change their minds from time to time. Or that they would benefit from explaining their own opinion, and not shouting down their opponents.

Much of the problem stems from what’s been called “the big sort” – the physical movement of people toward places where their neighbors will be more like-minded.

“Americans are less likely to live near and work with people who disagree with them than at any time since we’ve been measuring that,” French said.

But because people tend to become more extreme in their views when they only talk with those who agree with them, we’ve lost not only our willingness to engage with others but the belief we even need to do so.

How bad has it gotten?

“People are more likely to prefer their son or daughter marry a person of a different faith than a different political party,” French said, quipping that for many on the right, “eternal damnation is preferable to a Democrat.”

Although these attitudes concern politics, count French as someone who does not believe there’s a political solution.

Rather, a cultural solution is needed. And that’s where the personal courage comes in.

“We cannot allow ourselves to be intimidated into silence,” he said, because that silence becomes self-reinforcing and makes it harder to speak up the next time.

But the answer is not to fight fire with fire.

“The opposite of political correctness is not acting like a jerk,” French said. “It’s speaking the truth with grace and humility and fearlessness. There is such a thing as being fearlessly reasonable.”

Along with that is a legal corollary to the Golden Rule: “Defend the rights of others that you would like to exercise yourself.”

And an answer to the “snowflake” mentality on many college campuses: “Do your best to be unoffendable. Be a walking safe space for speech.”

French takes as much abuse on social media (specifically Twitter) as anyone I observe.

But while he acknowledges those platforms “put human nature on blast,” and not in a good way, he said they’re not the root cause of these problems.

“It’s as old as the high school cafeteria,” he said. “It’s peer pressure.”

As in that context, the answer to political correctness is to stand up to the peer pressure rather than conform to it to stay with the “in” crowd.

Contrary to some pleas, however, he isn’t for treating big tech companies like Facebook and Google as public utilities, or using antitrust power to break them up.

“If you have one ‘woke’ Google and you break into nine pieces, what are you going to have?” he posited. “Nine ‘woke’ Googles.”

The answer here is a mix of persuading the leaders of these behemoths not to stifle speech they don’t like, while encouraging entrepreneurs who want to compete with them.

The worst approach would be to weaken that strong legal environment for free speech, and let government regulators decide what’s OK to say.

“If there’s one thing we know about politics,” he warned those who have the upper hand today, “it’s that no party maintains control for long.”

(Kyle Wingfield is president and CEO of the Georgia Public Policy Foundation: www.georgiapolicy.org.)
